required_header.download_date: ClinicalTrials.gov processed this data on July 28, 2020
required_header.link_text: Link to the current ClinicalTrials.gov record.

clinical_study.brief_title: Using Mobile Health (mHealth) to Improve STI Treatment Adherence Among Adolescents
clinical_study.official_title: Leveraging Health Information Technology to Reduce Health Disparities in Adolescent Health Outcomes: A Patient-Centered Approach

brief_summary.textblock: We will conduct a randomized trial to compare differences in sexually transmitted infection (STI) treatment adherence between patients receiving text messages versus those receiving usual care (e.g. no text messages). We hypothesize that STI treatment adherence will be 20% higher among patients randomized to receipt of two-way text messaging services.

primary_outcome.description: Proportion of study participants who complete their medication as prescribed by self-report

secondary_outcome.description: Proportion of study participants who receive STI treatment; measured by prescription filling and/or receiving treatment at a healthcare facility

arm_group.description: Adolescents enrolled in this arm will receive treatment-related text messages.
Adolescents in this arm will receive usual care.

intervention.description: Adolescents will receive text messages to facilitate treatment adherence

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
- Adolescent patients seen in the Emergency Department who test positive for gonorrhea, chlamydia, or pelvic inflammatory disease and are prescribed outpatient antibiotic treatment.
Exclusion Criteria:
- Patients will be excluded if they are unable to understand English, are critically ill, have cognitive impairment or if they do not have access to a cellular telephone with text messaging capabilities.

responsible_party.investigator_title: Associate Professor of Pediatrics and Emergency Medicine
